title: Epic 1: Styling Architecture Migration
description: Migrate from monolithic 6,686-line CSS file to a scalable styling solution (Tailwind CSS or CSS Modules). This blocks all future UI work and affects developer productivity.

title: 1.1: Evaluate CSS approaches (Tailwind vs CSS Modules)
description: Research and decide between Tailwind CSS, CSS Modules, or other approaches. Document pros/cons, migration effort, and team preference. Create ADR (Architecture Decision Record).
notes:
## Decision: Tailwind CSS âœ…

**Decision Date:** 2026-02-14

**Chosen Approach:** Tailwind CSS

**Reasoning:**
1. Solves core problems (scoping, naming, maintainability)
2. Massive productivity gains (2-3x faster styling)
3. Tiny bundle size (only ships used CSS)
4. Perfect for React + TypeScript + Electron
5. Industry standard with huge community
6. Future-proof and well-maintained

**Trade-offs Accepted:**
- Learning curve (2-3 weeks to get comfortable)
- Longer initial migration (3-4 weeks vs 2-3 for CSS Modules)
- Different paradigm (utility-first vs component classes)

**Why Not CSS Modules:**
- Still requires writing CSS files
- Less productive long-term
- No built-in design system

**Next Steps:**
- Create implementation tickets
- Start with setup and configuration
- Migrate incrementally, keeping tests passing

title: Epic 3: State Management Split
description: Split the 2,663-line god object store (projectStore.ts) into 7-8 focused stores (UI, camera, selection, snap, etc.). Improves performance and maintainability.

title: 3.1: Design store split architecture
description: Design how to split projectStore into: projectStore (domain data), uiStore (modals/toast), cameraStore (viewport), selectionStore (selected items), snapStore (snap system), assemblyEditingStore (edit mode), licenseStore (feature limits). Document data flow and inter-store communication.
notes:
## Decision: Store Split Architecture Approved âœ…

**Decision Date:** 2026-02-14

**Approved Architecture:**

Split projectStore.ts (2,663 lines) into 7-8 focused stores:

1. **projectStore** (500-800 lines) - Core domain data
   - parts, stocks, groups, assemblies
   - snapGuides, cutList
   - project metadata (name, filePath, isDirty)
   - project settings (units, gridSize, kerf, overage)
   - stockConstraints, customShoppingItems

2. **uiStore** (200-300 lines) - UI/modal state
   - contextMenu, toast
   - pendingDeletePartIds
   - cutListModalOpen, saveAssemblyModalOpen
   - manualThumbnail

3. **cameraStore** (200-300 lines) - Camera/viewport
   - cameraState, cameraViewVectors
   - centerCameraRequested, centerCameraAtOriginRequested
   - displayMode, showGrid, showGrainDirection

4. **selectionStore** (300-400 lines) - Selection state
   - selectedPartIds, selectedGroupIds
   - hoveredPartId
   - transformMode
   - activeDragDelta
   - selectionBox
   - expandedGroupIds

5. **snapStore** (200-300 lines) - Snap system
   - snapToPartsEnabled
   - activeSnapLines
   - referencePartIds
   - activeReferenceDistances

6. **assemblyEditingStore** (200-300 lines) - Assembly editing
   - isEditingAssembly
   - editingAssemblyId
   - editingAssemblyName
   - previousProjectSnapshot

7. **clipboardStore** (100-150 lines) - Copy/paste
   - clipboard.parts
   - clipboard.groups

8. **licenseStore** (100-150 lines) - License/limits
   - licenseMode
   - feature limit checks

**Migration Strategy:**
- Extract stores incrementally
- Start with least-coupled (uiStore, cameraStore)
- Keep tests passing throughout
- Only projectStore persisted to file (others transient)

**Next Steps:**
- Create implementation tickets
- Start with UI and camera stores (lowest risk)
